snippet: As President Obama prepares to send the United States on what could be a yearslong military campaign, American intelligence agencies have concluded that the group poses no immediate threat to the United States.
abstract: American intelligence agencies are struggling to gauge threat posed by Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, even as United States prepares to act; American counterterrorism officials reviewing threats to United States believe ISIS has no ability to attack inside the US, therefore Al Qaeda and its affiliates remain the most immediate focus.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI, ERIC SCHMITT and MARK LANDLER
byline.contributor: Matt Apuzzo and James Risen contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: As President Obama prepares to send the United States on what could be a yearslong military campaign, American intelligence agencies have concluded that the group poses no immediate threat to the United States.

headline.main: Struggling to Gauge ISIS Threat, Even as U.S. Prepares to Act
headline.print_headline: Struggling to Gauge Threat, Even as U.S. Prepares to Act
